title: The CS Assistant Professor Handbook

last_post.content:
🚨 Book first draft is done! 🚨

The "CS Assistant Prof Handbook" is available here: https://vijay03.github.io/asstprofbook/

Chapters include:
- Chapter 1: The Assistant Prof Job
- Chapter 2: Students
- Chapter 3: Funding
- Chapter 4: Teaching
- Chapter 5: Research
- Chapter 6: Outreach
- Chapter 7: Service
- Chapter 8: Self-Care

The book will always be available online for free, but if you want to buy a nice Kindle version, you can pre-order on Amazon:

https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0BPLYLKQK

The ebook will be available on Amazon from Mar 3 onwards! You can pre-order now.

Would love to hear your thoughts about the book!

Please share this with new profs and grad students and undergraduate students who are aspiring to become profs one day!

title: https://mastodon.ngo

last_post.content:
#introduction

A few weeks ago there was a discussion about the need for a #Mastodon instance dedicated to NGOs, nonprofits, and folks in the human rights space.

So I got to work with @happy and @gillo and created https://mastodon.ngo! We're admin'ing this instance together and we'll be maintaining it for the long term.

If you or your organization or someone you know is interested in creating an account, let me know. You can also request an account here: https://mastodon.ngo/about

title: newyorker.com/magazine/2023/03...

last_post.content:
Take this with a grain of salt because I haven't finished the article yet, but I think liberal arts majors are in freefall because, unlike #STEM majors, I, personally, anecdotally, never saw any effort to funnel the English majors into lucrative post-college jobs. It's an attrition, largely, of the universities' own making: generations have learned you don't make enough money with your BA, but you'll still have those #studentloans all the same.

https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2023/03/06/the-end-of-the-english-major

title: gendergp.com/new-study-confirm...

last_post.content:
This is BIG. A new study in the Journal of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, has highlighted a regret rate of only 0.3% for gender-affirming surgeries.

To put that into context, the regret rate for knee replacements is around 20% and plastic surgery can be up to 65%. Gender-affirming surgery... 0.3% 🤷

Yet MORE scientific research debunking the misinformation that's spread about the trans and gender diverse community 🎉 Read more on this research below ❤️

https://www.gendergp.com/new-study-confirms-regret-rates-of-gender-affirming-surgery-are-non-existent/?ma=1

title: Meetings *are* the work - Elizabeth Ayer - Medium

last_post.content:
I get deeply frustrated by the whole "meetings aren't real work" thing, and I needed to put out into the world why, so I could move on.

Eventually I got my thoughts together with help from Peter Drucker, Chris Argyris, Annie Duke, Jeff Bezos, Erika Hall, Mary Parker Follett, Samo Burja and Aristotle.

Just published: https://medium.com/@ElizAyer/meetings-are-the-work-9e429dde6aa3

title: Stop Talking to Each Other and Start Buying Things: Three Decades of Survival in the Desert of Social Media

last_post.content:
Hi, folks. I've been a recluse for a while because...well, because social media has sucked. But I'm cautiously wading back in because @catvalente convinced me to by writing this amazing article:

https://catvalente.substack.com/p/stop-talking-to-each-other-and-start

Even with no followers, I am pleased that my first act on Mastodon is to encourage anyone and everyone to read it.

title: knightcolumbia.org/events/opti...

last_post.content: The harms of engagement optimization and algorithmic amplification are at a boiling point. A @knightcolumbia symposium (Apr 28/29, NYC & online) has a unique set of 17 new papers dissecting the issue and proposing responses. The authors span CS, law, philosophy, psychology, and more. Many have worked on these issues at social media companies. This might be the first time a group like this has come together. Hope to see you there. Author/speaker list & registration info: https://knightcolumbia.org/events/optimizing-for-what-algorithmic-amplification-and-society

title: 1 dataset. 100 visualizations.

last_post.content:
Are there really 100 different ways to #visualise even a *very* small dataset?

As the intro so eloquently says:

“Every time we turn a set of data into a visual depiction, hundreds of design choices have to be made to make the data tell the best story possible”….

I really enjoyed scanning this. It’s not done in #rstats but it’s the sort of thing that is probably of interest to the community.

https://100.datavizproject.com

title: Better incentives are needed to reward academic software development - Nature Ecology & Evolution

last_post.content:
This hits a very soft spot. There is no credit for maintaining packages in #openscience.

I maintain 11 #rstats packages, good for close to ~200K downloads. They are used in teaching, analysis, papers, by government agencies, you name it.

Credit, as in citations, hardly any. Pull requests, hardly any, feature requests and not reading the docs (too many).

#academicmastodon #AcademicChatter #opensource

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41559-023-02008-w

title: How I Broke Into a Bank Account With an AI-Generated Voice

last_post.content:
RT @josephfcox@twitter.com

New: we proved it could be done. I used an AI replica of my voice to break into my bank account. The AI tricked the bank into thinking it was talking to me. Could access my balances, transactions, etc. Shatters the idea that voice biometrics are foolproof https://www.vice.com/en/article/dy7axa/how-i-broke-into-a-bank-account-with-an-ai-generated-voice

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/josephfcox/status/1628798416754032643

title: Acute and postacute sequelae associated with SARS-CoV-2 reinfection - Nature Medicine

last_post.content:
I sent this chart to a dear friend yesterday because I think it's important for people to understand the risks they're taking even though the message we all get is that COVID is over.

Big picture: with every infection, the risk of every complication goes up.

You have not "gotten it over with" after your first infection.

I'm tired of it. You're tired of it. But #CovidIsNotOver.

If you have questions, read the paper: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-022-02051-3

title: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11305v1

last_post.content:
To detect if text comes from LM X, randomly modify it and get X's logprobs of the original and the mod.

If p(original) > p(mod), classify as LM generated.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11305v1

title: rewe.de/nachhaltigkeit/unsere-...

last_post.content:
TIL that one of Germany’s biggest supermarket chains will stop producing printed marketing flyers this year. Their main argument is the climate and the numbers are insane:

Yearly savings:

- 390.000 m3 of wood
- 70.000 tons of CO2
- 380.000.000 kWh of electric energy

It’s the CO2 equivalent of roughly 60.000 ICE cars and the energy could power 100.000 4-person households for a year 🤯

https://www.rewe.de/nachhaltigkeit/unsere-ziele/projekte/klimaschutz/papierlos/

title: CoSocial

last_post.content:
A comment on VC-funded companies with products in the fediverse:

My company, StatusNet, ran identi.ca for a long time on VC funding.

It's hard to get a 10x return in markets where open standards prevail. But it's fine to try.

There are other ways to fund services in the fediverse. https://cosocial.ca/ is a cooperative, for example.

If the fediverse remains diverse and competitive, and community, coop and family servers have a place, I'm not opposed to VC-backed companies participating.

title: Underrecognized: Extremist murders are usually from right-wing actors

last_post.content:
Last May, YouGov asked Americans if more extremism-linked murders were committed by the left or right. Republicans said left; Democrats right.

The reality? Way more on the right. Almost all, when you exclude radical Islamist actors and all in 2022. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/02/28/extremism-right-wing-deaths/

title: Language Is Not All You Need: Aligning Perception with Language Models

last_post.content:
"In this work, we introduce Kosmos-1, a Multimodal Large Language Model (MLLM) [...] results show that Kosmos-1 achieves impressive performance on (i) language understanding, generation, and even OCR-free NLP (directly fed with document images), (ii) perception-language tasks, including multimodal dialogue, image captioning, visual question answering, and (iii) vision tasks, such as image recognition with descriptions (specifying classification via text instructions)"¹

¹ https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14045

title: Introduction to Critical Digital Librarianship - Library Juice Academy

last_post.content:
#library, #archives, #CulturalHeritage friends!

A quick reminder that I’m teaching a course with Library Juice Academy: “Introduction to #Critical #Digital #Librarianship”

We will engage with #feminist, #antiracist, #queer, and other critical frameworks as they intersect with digital librarianship.

Topics include #ethical digital selection, responsible #open #data, reparative #description, critical #software review.

title: Chapter 7 Confidence Intervals | Improving Your Statistical Inferences

last_post.content:
"One might intuitively believe that an effect is only statistically significant if the confidence interval around the individual means do not overlap, but this is not true. The significance test is related to the confidence interval around the mean difference."

Thanks, @lakens, dealing exactly with an "intuitive" comment from a referee. https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/confint.html#overlapping-confidence-intervals

#statistics

title: The People's search engine | PeARS

last_post.content:
#introduction 🙂

I've been a researcher in the field of #computationallinguistics for over 15 years. Interested in #semantics, #cognitivescience, energy-efficient and ethical #AI systems. I've worked at the universities of Cambridge, Potsdam, Stuttgart and Trento, with a brief stint at Pompeu Fabra in Barcelona.

I am one of the core developers of PeARS (https://pearsproject.org/), a slow but friendly open-source project aiming at developing a fully private, decentralised Web search engine.

title: Community Interaction and Conflict on the Web

last_post.content:
Community Interaction and Conflict on the Web

https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.03697


"Users organize themselves into communities on web platforms. These communities can interact with one another, often leading to conflicts and toxic interactions. ... We show that such conflicts tend to be initiated by a handful of communities---less than 1% of communities start 74% of conflicts."

#OnlineCommunities

title: Use your reference interview skills to do user research - Choice 360

last_post.content:
I wrote about how the reference interview is similar to doing user research: https://www.choice360.org/libtech-insight/use-your-reference-interview-skills-to-do-user-research/

The skills of an adept reference librarian include building rapport with the patron, posing productive questions, and avoiding being judgmental. These skills are transferable to doing user research!

title: pacscenter.stanford.edu/event/...

last_post.content:
Independent research on technology and society is a critical public good with real power, which is why it needs defending.

Today at Stanford, I'lll be joining Kaveh Waddell (Consumer Reports), Touissaint Nothias (Stanford), and Elizabeth Eagen (CAT Lab) to discuss the Coalition for Independent Technology Research.

The talk, at 1:30pm PT, will be accessible online. Thanks for hosting us @p2173!

https://pacscenter.stanford.edu/event/meet-the-coalition-for-independent-tech-research/
